pressures_threats_info.pressures_info: Xe - Threats and pressures from outside the EU territory: Illegal shooting during migration mainly in Lebanon, Syria, Turkey, Georgia and the Caucasus region. Xo - Threats and pressures from outside the Member State: Illegal shootings during migration mainly in Greece and Malta.

measures_purpose.desc: Maintain the current distribution, population and/or habitat for the species

measures_response.desc: Short-term results (within the current reporting period, 2013-2018)

code.desc: Reinstate appropriate agricultural practices to address abandonment, including mowing, grazing, burning or equivalent measures
Adapt/change forest management and exploitation practices

conservation_measures.measures_info: LIFE+ project "Conservation arrangements for Lesser Spotted Eagle in Latvia": http://www.mazaiserglis.lv/en/about-project The breeding sites of the species are protected by establishing microreserves. Species foraging habitats are protected under the Rural Development Programme (through support payments for farmers) by defining biologically valuable grasslands for birds. Latvian Fund for Nature and JSC “Latvia’s State Forests” is deploying online webcams at nests of the species for educational and research purposes.

bird_report.spa_info: Population size calculated as a fraction of habitat suitability in network multiplied by national population estimate (based on unpublished species conservation action plan). As species is rare, it is not covered by neither bacground or Natura 2000 monitoring, therefore population trend is unknown, although, some experts suggest stronger population decline in the network due to higher tourism activity.

bird_report.population_trend_info: Methods for detection of the Eurasian Pygmy Owl in Latvia were first discovered in 2002 and more widely introduced in 2003, adopted in monitoring in 2004. Every estimate of Latvian population before 2003 is entirely unreliable underestimate (including references suggested in guidelines). Therefore the best existing knowledge (since 2004) is reported.

Main pressures are present also within network as species conservation action plan suggest (unpublished).

bird_report.population_trend_info: Estimates around 1994 (10-30 pairs) and 1999 (10-30 pairs) probably overestimated the population, there are only three confirmed observations since 1986, yet, there was a possible breeding during 1980-1984.

bird_report.spa_info: Population size calculated as a fraction of habitat suitability in network multiplied by national population estimate (based on unpublished species conservation action plan). Due to implementation of Natura 2000 site monitoring, population trend is reported as equal to national trend obtained from statistically robust scheme. Main pressures are present also within network as species conservation action plan suggest (unpublished).

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Priednieks J., Strazds M., Strazds A., Petrins A. 1989. Latvian Breeding Bird Atlas 1980-1984. Riga: Zinatne. Strazds M., Priednieks J., Vaverins G. 1994. [Size of Latvian bird populations.] (in Latvian) In: Putni dabā, 4: 3–18 Avotiņš sen., A., Graubics, G., Ķemlers, A., Krēsliņš, V., Ķuze, J., Ļoļāns, U., 1999. Number and breeding densities of owls in Latvia: studies in sample plots. Vogelwelt 120, 333–337. Eionet, 2014. Bird population status and trends at the EU and Member State levels [WWW Document]. URL https://bd.eionet.europa.eu/article12/summary
bird_report.population_trend_info: Last confirmed breeding was in 2002, since 2012, there has been (until 2019) only one observation of bird present in a site during breeding season for more than two weeks. The rest of observations might be vagrants (every year) due to late breeding of species and have only one repeated observation even in sites rich with field ornithologist attention. Every previous estimate since 1980-1984 estimated population ranging from 0 to 5 breeding pairs.

bird_report.spa_info: Population size calculated as a fraction of habitat suitability in network multiplied by national population estimate (based on unpublished species conservation action plan). Due to implementation of Natura 2000 site monitoring, population trend is reported as equal to national trend obtained from statistically robust scheme. Main pressures are present also within network as species conservation action plan suggest (unpublished).

bird_report.population_trend_long_sources: Priednieks J., Strazds M., Strazds A., Petrins A. 1989. Latvian Breeding Bird Atlas 1980-1984. Riga: Zinatne. Strazds M., Priednieks J., Vaverins G. 1994. [Size of Latvian bird populations.] (in Latvian) In: Putni dabā, 4: 3–18
bird_report.population_trend_info: There has never been confirmed breeding in Latvia. Though, some occasional observations exist. Since last observation in 2016 with vocalising pair, biannual acoustic (spring and autumn) monitorings at the most probable possible breeding sites exist as well as monitoring of artificial nest-platforms located in (supposed to be) favourable habitats for species exist, but no more than irregular observations. No even annually (or at least two years in 2013-2017) heard bird.

bird_report.distribution_trend_info: There has never been confirmed breeding in Latvia. Though, some occasional observations exist. Since last observation in 2016 with vocalising pair, (bi-)annual acoustic (spring or spring and autumn) monitorings at the most probable possible breeding sites exist as well as monitoring of artificial nest-platforms located in (supposed to be) favourable habitats for species exist, but no more than irregular observations. No even annually (or at least two years in 2013-2017) heard bird. Previously observations with approximately the same regularity: four confirmed observations since 1910 but all since 2006.

bird_report.measures_taken: A species action plan has been prepared, however, it never got officially adopted Aunins A. 1999. [Action Plan for Conservation of Great Snipe] (in Latvian with English Summary). Riga, Latvian Ornithological Society. Nevertheless, majority of actions required have been fulfilled. Preparation and adoption of a new action plan is needed. Habitats of the species are protected under the Rural Development Programme (through support payments for farmers) by defining biologically valuable grasslands for birds.

bird_report.measures_taken: Approximately 30% of the population is covered by two Natura 2000 sites, for both of which management plans have been adopted. Monitoring of population size and breeding success is carried out. Safe nest boxes are provided. Project "Improving of the conservation status of specially protected bird species in Natura 2000 site "Adazi"" took place from 2013. till 2018. European Roller was one of the target species of the project. The breeding sites of the species may be protected by establishing microreserves.

effectiveness_SAPs.desc: further deteriorating away from the plan’s aim/objective(s)

pressures_threats_info.pressures_source: Strazds M., Ķerus V. (2017). [Action Plan fot the Hazel Grouse (Bonasa bonasia) in Latvia for the period 2017.–2026.] (in Latvian). Latvian Ornithological society: https://www.daba.gov.lv/upload/File/DOC/SAP_mezirbe_17_LV.pdf
pressures_threats_info.pressures_info: IAS union concern : Nyctereutes procyonoides Gray, 1834; B29 - Other forestry activities, excluding those relating to agro-forestry: Disturbance caused by forestry during the breeding season. L06 - Interspecific relations (competition, predation, parasitism, pathogens): Predation: Vulpes Vulpes, Martes martes, Meles meles, Sus scrofa. B02 - Conversion to other types of forests including monocultures: The proportion of spruce stands. G09 - Harvesting or collecting of other wild plants and animals (excluding hunting and leisure fishing): Berry picking.

conservation_measures.measures_info: Project "Improving of the conservation status of specially protected bird species in Natura 2000 site "Adazi"" took place from 2013. till 2018. Tawny Pipit was one of the target species of the project. The Nature Conservation Agency in 2018 commenced a monitoring programme at the coast for this species. Habitats of the species are protected under the Rural Development Programme (through support payments for farmers) by defining biologically valuable grasslands for birds.
